title: Sources
text:
The dataset used in this analysis is the Adult Census Income dataset, which can be found on Kaggle. This dataset includes demographic information and income levels for adults in the United States. It was originally extracted from the 1994 Census database.




Title: Adult Census Income
Source: Kaggle
Link: Adult Census Income Dataset on Kaggle
Description: The dataset includes the following variables: age, workclass, education, marital status, occupation, relationship, race, sex, hours per week, native country, and income level. The primary goal is to predict whether an individual’s income exceeds $50K per year based on these attributes.
Usage: This dataset was used to explore the impact of race and gender on income and to build predictive models to estimate income levels.




If you use this dataset in your work, please cite it as follows:
Bansal, Lovish. “Adult Census Income.” Kaggle, 2020. https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/lovishbansal123/adult-census-income.

title: Income Prediction Based on Race and Gender
text: This project explores the impact of race and gender on income using a Bayesian Regression Model. By examining these demographic factors, we can gain insights into how they influence income levels.

title: Income Prediction Based on Race and Gender
text: This project explores the impact of race and gender on income using a Bayesian Regression Model. By examining these demographic factors, we can gain insights into how they influence income levels.

title: Income Prediction Based on Race and Gender
text:
Overview
The dataset contains demographic information such as race, gender, age, education, and income level. We will focus on race and gender as key predictors of income, applying a Bayesian Regression Model to estimate the relationship.

title: Income Prediction Based on Race and Gender
text:
Visualization
The following ridge plot shows the distribution of income by race and gender, with overlaid median income levels to provide a point of reference for comparison.

title: About
text:
This website explores the impact of race and gender on income using the Adult Census Income dataset. The data provides insights into how various demographic factors influence income levels.


The objective of this project is to analyze and visualize the data to uncover patterns and insights into income distribution across different races and genders. The following sections cover:

Home: Introduction to the website and an overview of the project with examples and visuals.
Visual Analysis: Methods used to analyze the data with various models and visualizations.
Sources: Information about the origin of the data and its contents.
About: Details about the project and the author.




The dataset contains demographic information and income levels for adults in the United States. It includes the following columns:

age: Age of the individual
workclass: Type of work (e.g., Private, Self-emp-not-inc, etc.)
fnlwgt: Final weight, used for statistical adjustments
education: Highest level of education achieved
education-num: Number of years of education
marital-status: Marital status of the individual
occupation: Type of occupation
relationship: Relationship status (e.g., Husband, Not-in-family, etc.)
race: Race of the individual
sex: Gender of the individual
capital-gain: Capital gains
capital-loss: Capital losses
hours-per-week: Hours worked per week
native-country: Country of origin
income: Income level (<=50K or >50K)




I’m Harshil Kurapati, a rising senior in high school with a passion for data science. This project is part of my exploration into demographic data and aims to provide valuable insights into the factors affecting income levels.
You can find more about my work on GitHub or reach out to me via email at ckurapat@gmail.com.



This project was created as a part of Kane’s Data Science Bootcamp, where I learned essential skills in data analysis and visualization to tackle real-world challenges.

title: Income Prediction Based on Race and Gender
text:
Takeaway
The analysis reveals that both race and gender significantly influence income levels, with disparities evident across different racial groups and between genders. These findings highlight persistent inequalities in income distribution, underscoring the need for further exploration and potential policy interventions to address these disparities.
